Dear Ms. Olik:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
February 3, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Stephanie S Meeuwenberg, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
• (g) If the employee has criminal
convictions, the institution shall complete a
written evaluation of the convictions that
addresses the nature of the conviction, the
length of time since the conviction, and the
relationship of the conviction to regulated
activity for the purpose of determining
suitability for employment in the institution.
2

Two of two new employee files reviewed that required a written evaluation based
on criminal convictions did not have them completed.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during the licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
• 2024 Renewal: CAP was recorded during this reporting period as a result
of the Renewal inspection completed on January 30, 2024. This CAP
contained one violation of CCI Rule 400.4154 in that there was one
treatment plan completed late. The CAP contained action steps for a 25-
day reminder for initial treatment plans to be started for youth upon
placement. This CAP was completed successfully and there have been
no violations for this rule since.
• Special Investigation 2024SIC0001523 with CAP approval on 8/28/2024
was a result of violation for eye-on checks not to exceed fifteen minutes.
3

The agency implemented a review of camera footage to ensure proper
supervision is occurring, as well as check-ins with youth placed at the
facility to ensure they are being supervised. The agency is currently
complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor
CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the agency’s
budget and the agency’s financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. Chief Administrator reported
during this period under review the CAP has been implemented and has rectified
the concerns related to supervision. The program does not have any identified
barriers to compliance with the rules. The Chief Administrator reported the census
has been very low throughout this period under review, staffing has been stable,
and they are complying with licensing rules.
Staff and Youth Interviews
The Director and Assistant Director were interviewed as they were the only staff
present on the day of the onsite inspection. They did not have any questions or
concerns regarding the program, however noted the census has been very low for
the past several months and there is a meeting set with the judges to discuss the
ongoing need for a non-secure detention center.
There were no youth on the day of the onsite inspection, therefore no youth were
interviewed.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An onsite inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on February 3, 2025.
There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
4

Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
